section.title: Building Repositories
section.para: During the build process, System Studio gathers content, processes it, creates a repository, and optionally runs scripts to test, deploy or maintain client machines.

section.title: Input
section.para: System Studio uses three classes of input: a base operating system repository, additional package repositories, and configuration files and scripts.

itemizedlist.listitem: Base Operating System Repository. System Studio requires a CentOS-compatible operating system repository as input for creating new repositories. Currently supported operating system repositories include CentOS and Red Hat Enterprise Linux, versions 5 and 6 for i386 and x86_64 architectures. See for more information.

Additional Package Repositories. System Studio uses RPM package repositories to locate and download additional software components for the repository. A typical repository definition will specify multiple additional input repositories, including a operating system update repository, and repositories made available from other internal and external providers. See for more information.

Configuration Files and Scripts. The final category of repository content is user-provided configuration files and scripts. Files are copied and scripts are executed during client machine installation and updates. For more information, see .

section.title: Process
section.para: System Studio uses information from the to gather repository content. It uses this information to complete three primary steps.

listitem.para: Create repository-specific RPM packages. System Studio creates two types of packages, the and optional . The release-rpm contains System Studio-generated YUM update configuration. Config-rpm packages contain user-provided files and scripts specified in the repository definition. Both are discussed under .

During this step, System Studio also creates a , if one does not exist, in the same folder as the repository definition. The file has a .dat extension. This file is used to store System Studio generated input data, such as release numbers for generated RPMs, that should be maintained along with the repository definition.

itemizedlist.listitem: Assemble a package repository. Using the repository definition, System Studio compiles a list of required packages. It then resolves package dependencies, downloads packages, and creates a complete, consistent package repository. The package repository is used during network installations to client machines. It is also used during client machine updates.

Customize system installation images (optional). For system-type repositories, System Studio downloads network installation images from the CentOS-compatible repository and modifies them to include repository-specific information. System Studio can be used to completely automate client installations. The chapters on and describe this in detail.

section.para: System Studio stores repository content, both input and generated, in the cache folder, by default /var/cache/systemstudio/. It reuses information from the cache on subsequent runs, where possible, to improve build performance.

section.title: Output
section.para: System Studio outputs a complete repository, a repository data file and a log file.

itemizedlist.listitem: Repository. The primary output of the build process is a complete YUM package repository containing RPM packages. For system-type repositories, the repository also contains system installation images. Together, the YUM repository and system installation images support the complete range of system and application deployment and maintenance scenarios. See the chapters on , and for more information.
Repository Data File. As mentioned above, System Studio creates a during the build process. This file is used to track System Studio generated input information.
System Studio Log File. System Studio sends output both to the screen and to a log file, located by default at /var/log/systemstudio.log.

section.title: Test, Deploy and Update
section.para:
The repository generated by System Studio is used to perform testing, deployment and maintenance to client machines. These steps can be performed in one of three ways:
Manually by the user or administrator.
Automatically by System Studio using deployment scripts.
Or, because repositories are in a standard format, automatically by any systems management system that can deploy and maintain native CentOS and Red Hat Enterprise Linux systems.
See the chapters on , and for additional information.
